awd_titl_txt: Research on an International Network for STEM Media Making and Student-Led Participatory Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research in Service to Practice project, a collaboration of Pepperdine University and the New York Hall of Science, will establish a network of STEM-related Media Making Clubs comprised of after-school students aged 12 - 19 and teachers in the U.S. and in three other countries: Kenya, Namibia and Finland.  The media produced by the students may include a range of formats such as videos, short subject films, games, computer programs and specialized applications like interactive books.  The content of the media produced by the students will focus on the illustration and teaching of STEM topics, where the shared media is intended to help other students become enthused about and learn the science. This proposal builds on the principal investigator's previous work on localized media clubs by now creating an international network in which after-school students and teachers will collaborate at a distance with other clubs. 
 
The central research questions for the project pertain to three themes at the intersection of learning, culture and collaboration: the impact of participatory teaching, virtual networks, and intercultural, global competence. The research will combine qualitative, cross-cultural and big data methods.  Critical to the innovation of the project, the research team will also develop a network assessment tool, adapting epistemic network analysis methods to the needs of this initiative.
   
This work is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
How does collaborative STEM project-based learning change when the participating students - who represent fundamentally distinct cultures, countries, and economic and social backgrounds - work together over synchronous and asynchronous platforms? How does international collaboration shape identity formation of adolescents? Differences in where people live and in our cultures factor deeply into social and economic fractures in US and global society. Can students working together across such boundaries experience virtual presence and shared meaning-making through project collaborations in ways that allow deeper appreciation of each other's differences, and reduce such divisions? Featuring students and teachers who collaborated with one another weekly from sites in numerous countries, most recently including the US, Kenya, Mexico, Brazil, the United Arab Emirates, and Singapore, the IC4 (International Community for Collaborative Content Creation, ic4.site) project explored the intersection of learning, culture, and collaboration through an international digital makerspace.

IC4 project outcomes blended intellectual merit and broader impact outcomes:

  • IC4 operationalized commitments to broadening participation, diversity, belonging, and equity. It did so by creating a context in which a rich combination of participants across racial and gender lines, across Global South/Global North countries, both well-resourced and poorly resourced, mixed and matched roles of teachers and learners in learning and sharing STEM topics. This resulted in authentic scientific discourse and knowledge building occurring synchronously during online global meet-ups and asynchronously in text-based reflection and collaboration work in platforms such as Google Docs and Slack.
  • The project succeeded in producing an increase in female minority leadership among the IC4 student participants in the U.S., notably in leading python-coding peer learning efforts and facilitation of the weekly global meet-ups.
  • Application of epistemic network analysis (ENA) in the project's research and data analysis was a flagship element of the project's research strand. This entailed material contribution to the early formation of the ascendant quantitative ethnography community, in which NSF and STEM/EDU have contributed significantly.
  • Articles applying ENA and quantitative ethnography more generally contributed to continued dissemination of research efforts that resulted in over 30 papers and presentations in the products and dissemination section of the final project report and of the ic4.site webpage.
  • These efforts in ENA and quantitative ethnography more generally also contributed to the nascent field exploring affect in multimodal data analysis with options for machine learning to automate the qualitative coding of certain constructs in online global meet-ups.
  • IC4 contributed regularly to the national STEM for All Video Showcase forum. For six consecutive years, IC4's contribution was the most actively comment thread in the forum (note, the videos were primarily produced by active and recent IC4 alums): The most recent, https://stemforall2022.videohall.com/presentations/2474, also received both Public Choice recognition.
  • The project provided multiple ways for teachers to actively engage in taking on roles of researchers and research project evaluators.
  • A comprehensive summative evaluation of the project is attached to the project's final NSF report.
  • One other important outcome of the project as it approached its conclusion involved in-depth reflection by the teachers in the project and the project leaders on articulating the potential of informal collaborations of the kind IC4 represents. This led to a significant conceptual shift that our data collection and observation prompted. IC4 originated in the construct of participatory teaching, but it evolved to a larger view, that we were aiming to have youngsters form different understandings of themselves, of each other, and of STEM content. Participatory teaching helped adolescents reach these understandings, but the project benefitted from a more encompassing approach. We also recognized that our capacity to experiment with approaches not only was time-limited but was limited by our own ways of thinking. Thus, we began looking at our project through the lens of adolescent identity formation and asked teachers to share more how the project could unfold in its final year. The desire to have more expansive agency for teachers in building the model dovetailed with NSF's priorities on broadening participation. These shifts and changes became foundational to conceptualizing what we eventually submitted successfully to the AISL-2022 funding cycle (NSF 22151613). While AISL-2022 proposal development was separate from and was not underwritten by IC4, the thinking and data collection it represents is a direct and key outcome of the project. The learnings and progressing of thinking emerging from IC4 have now led to a next-generation model.
